Cedric Beust wrote:

> Take one of your classes with more than ten methods.
> 
> Can you really say that all the public methods of this class can be invoked
> at all time without any pre-requisite?

Yes.


> I would be very surprised if the answer was yes (it would mean your
> application is basically based on a bunch of static methods acting on
> stateless objects).


Not at all. That's what class invariants are for. Each public method is 
atomic. It is invoked when an object is any legal state and when the 
method returns it is always careful to leave the object in one of the 
legal states (barring bad synchronization and complicated multithreaded 
issues).

Each method must carefully document it's behavior under all legal 
states. In a few cases that might lead to an exception being thrown but 
that's rare. I never throw an IllegalStateException. I do throw 
IllegalArgumentExceptions or equivalent, and I do throw exceptions that 
indicate a problem in the environment external to my code. I suppose you 
might consider this a prerequisite violation. (For instance, the DNS 
server running might be a prerequisite to looking up a name with a DNS 
class.) However, a situation where public method A must be invoked 
before method B is a code smell. This normally indicates to me that 
neither A nor B should be public. Instead we should make A and B private 
and create a method C that invokes A, then B.
